{"index": 517, "sae_prompt": "The following memorandum is from the president of Primo Doll Manufacturing, Inc.\n\"According to a survey last year of parents who purchased the Elkie, our most popular doll, 90 percent reported that although their children were extremely satisfied with the doll's features, the doll quickly wore out with use. In a follow-up survey of the same parents, 80 percent reported that they would recommend a more durable version of the doll to their friends. In response to these surveys, we have created the Elkie-Advanced Doll, which has similar features to the original Elkie Doll but is manufactured using the same higher quality materials used by Optima Doll Manufacturing, our most successful competitor. Because parents can now purchase the beloved Elkie doll and be sure that it won't quickly wear out with use, we predict that our profits will exceed those of Optima Doll Manufacturing this year.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what questions would need to be answered in order to decide whether the prediction and the argument on which it is based are reasonable. Be sure to explain how the answers to these questions would help to evaluate the prediction.", "aae_prompt": "Check it, the memo comin' from the big boss of Primo Doll Manufacturing, Inc.\n\"Peep this, last year we hollered at some parents who copped the Elkie, that's our top doll, right? Then we hit up them same folks again, and 80 percent was like, 'Yeah, we'd put our peoples on to a tougher version of the doll.' So, we went ahead and cooked up this Elkie-Advanced Doll. Because parents can now purchase the beloved Elkie doll and be sure that it won't quickly wear out with use, we predict that our profits will exceed those of Optima Doll Manufacturing this year.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what questions would need to be answered in order to decide whether the prediction and the argument on which it is based are reasonable. Be sure to explain how the answers to these questions would help to evaluate the prediction.", "sae_essay": "The prediction made by the president of Primo Doll Manufacturing, Inc. that their profits will exceed those of Optima Doll Manufacturing this year is based on the assumption that the Elkie-Advanced Doll, which has similar features to the original Elkie Doll but is manufactured using higher quality materials, will be more durable and therefore more popular among parents. However, there are several questions that need to be answered in order to determine whether this prediction is reasonable.\n\nFirstly, it is important to know whether the sample of parents surveyed is representative of the entire population of parents who purchase dolls. If the sample is biased towards parents who are more likely to purchase dolls with durability in mind, then the results of the survey may not accurately reflect the preferences of all parents. Additionally, it would be useful to know the sample size of the survey and the margin of error to determine the reliability of the results.\n\nSecondly, it is important to consider the potential drawbacks of the Elkie-Advanced Doll. While the use of higher quality materials may make the doll more durable, it may also make it more expensive, which could be a deterrent for some parents. Furthermore, the Elkie-Advanced Doll may not have any new features that would make it stand out from the original Elkie Doll or other dolls on the market. If parents are not willing to pay a higher price for a more durable doll, or if they do not see the value in the Elkie-Advanced Doll's features, then the prediction of increased profits may not come to fruition.\n\nThirdly, it would be useful to know more about Optima Doll Manufacturing's products and business strategy. If Optima Doll Manufacturing has a strong brand reputation or offers other unique features that are not available in the Elkie-Advanced Doll, then parents may still choose to purchase their products over the Elkie-Advanced Doll, despite its durability. Additionally, if Optima Doll Manufacturing has a more extensive distribution network or stronger marketing efforts, they may be able to reach a wider audience and sell more dolls than Primo Doll Manufacturing, even if the Elkie-Advanced Doll is more durable.\n\nLastly, it would be important to consider the potential impact of external factors on the doll market. For example, if there is a shift in consumer preferences towards more eco-friendly or sustainable products, then the Elkie-Advanced Doll's use of higher quality materials may not be seen as a selling point. Additionally, if there is an economic downturn, parents may be less likely to purchase dolls altogether, regardless of their durability.\n\nIn conclusion, while the prediction made by the president of Primo Doll Manufacturing, Inc. is based on some encouraging survey results, there are still several questions that need to be answered in order to determine its reasonableness. The answers to these questions would help to evaluate the prediction by providing a more comprehensive understanding of the market, the competition, and the potential drawbacks of the Elkie-Advanced Doll.", "aae_essay": "Here's a breakdown of some questions that could help determine whether Primo Doll Manufacturing, Inc.'s prediction of surpassing Optima Doll Manufacturing's sales is solid:\n\n1. What are the specific features of the Elkie-Advanced Doll that make it more durable than the original Elkie?\n\nAnswering this question would help determine whether the improvements made to the Elkie-Advanced Doll are significant enough to justify the claim that it won't break down as fast as the original Elkie. Additionally, this information could be used to compare the Elkie-Advanced Doll's features to those of Optima Doll Manufacturing's products to assess whether Primo Doll Manufacturing, Inc. is truly using \"better materials\" as they claim.\n\n2. What was the sample size and selection process for the 90% and 80% of parents who expressed satisfaction with the original Elkie and interest in a tougher version, respectively?\n\nUnderstanding the sample size and selection process used to gather these statistics is crucial to determine whether they are reliable and representative of the larger consumer population. A small or biased sample could lead to inaccurate conclusions and an unreliable prediction of consumer behavior.\n\n3. How does the cost of producing the Elkie-Advanced Doll compare to the original Elkie and Optima Doll Manufacturing's products?\n\nThis question would help determine whether the use of \"better materials\" and improved durability will result in a higher production cost for the Elkie-Advanced Doll. If the production cost is significantly higher, it could negatively impact Primo Doll Manufacturing, Inc.'s profit margins and potentially threaten their ability to compete with Optima Doll Manufacturing.\n\n4. What is the current market share of Primo Doll Manufacturing, Inc. and Optima Doll Manufacturing, and how has it changed over time?\n\nUnderstanding the current market share and trends in market share for both companies would provide context for evaluating the feasibility of Primo Doll Manufacturing, Inc.'s prediction. If Optima Doll Manufacturing has a significantly larger market share and has been consistently gaining ground, it may be challenging for Primo Doll Manufacturing, Inc. to surpass their sales.\n\n5. What is the average lifespan of a doll in a child's play and how does it relate to the durability of the Elkie-Advanced Doll?\n\nThis question would help determine whether the improved durability of the Elkie-Advanced Doll will genuinely meet consumer demands. However, in order to determine whether this prediction is reasonable, several questions need to be answered.\n\nFirstly, it is important to know whether the sample of parents surveyed is representative of the entire population of parents who purchase dolls. If the sample is biased or too small, the results of the survey may not accurately reflect the opinions of all parents. If the definitions are too vague or subjective, the results of the survey may not accurately reflect the experiences of all parents. Furthermore, it would be helpful to know the specific features of the Elkie-Advanced Doll that make it more durable than the original Elkie Doll, as well as the cost of producing these features. This information would help to determine whether the higher quality materials used in the Elkie-Advanced Doll are truly worth the additional cost.\n\nThirdly, it would be useful to know the market share of Primo Doll Manufacturing, Inc. and Optima Doll Manufacturing, as well as the sales figures for both companies. This information would help to determine whether the demand for a more durable doll is truly there, and whether the Elkie-Advanced Doll is likely to meet this demand.\n\nIn conclusion, in order to determine whether the prediction made by the president of Primo Doll Manufacturing, Inc. is reasonable, several questions need to be answered. {"index": 516, "sae_prompt": "The following memo was published by the Welzaton City Commission.\n\"A recent nationwide study of the effectiveness of wearing a safety helmet while bicycling indicates that ten years ago approximately 35 percent of all bicyclists reported wearing helmets, whereas today that number is nearly 80 percent. Another study, however, cites a 200 percent increase in the number of serious accidents involving bicycles during the same period. Meanwhile, results of a local survey of frequent bicycle riders indicate that 75 percent of those riders feel 'much safer' on busy roads when they wear helmets than when they don't. Clearly, the best explanation for the rise in bicycle-related accidents is that bicyclists take more risks now than they did ten years ago because they feel safer when they are wearing helmets.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss one or more alternative explanations that could rival the proposed explanation and explain how your explanation(s) can plausibly account for the facts presented in the argument.", "aae_prompt": "Check it, the Welzaton City Commission done dropped this memo:\n\"Aight, so this study from all over the country been lookin' at how good it is to rock a safety helmet when you out here pedalin'. But peep this, another study throwin' out there that we got a 200 percent jump in them bad wrecks with bikes in the same time frame. And then, you got this local poll where they hollered at people who ride a lot, and 75 percent of 'em say they feel way more chill on them crowded streets when they got their helmet on than when they rollin' without. So they sayin', for real, the reason we seein' more of them bike accidents is 'cause cats on bikes be takin' more chances nowadays since they feel all snug in their helmets.\"\n\nAight, so what you need to do is come up with some other reasons that might be why we seein' more of these bike mess-ups. You gotta break down how what you thinkin' could really be what's up, given all the stuff they laid out in that argument.", "esl_prompt": "The following memo was publish by the Welzaton City Commission.\n\"A recent nationwide study of the effectiveness of wearing a safety helmet while bicycling indicates that ten years ago approximately 35 percent of all bicyclist reported wearing helmets, whereas today that number is nearly 80 percent. Another study, however, cites a 200 percent increase in the number of serious accidents involving bicycles during the same period. Meanwhile, results of a local survey of frequent bicycle riders indicate that 75 percent of those riders feel 'much safer' on busy roads when they wear helmets than when they don't. Clearly, the best explanation for the rise in bicycle-related accidents is that bicyclists take more risks now than they did ten years ago because they feel safer when they are wearing helmets.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss one or more alternative explanations that could rival the proposed explanation and explain how your explanation(s) can plausibly account for the facts presented in the argument.", "sae_essay": "The memo published by the Welzaton City Commission suggests that the increase in serious accidents involving bicycles can be attributed to bicyclists taking more risks due to a false sense of security provided by wearing helmets. However, there are alternative explanations that could rival this proposed explanation and provide alternative accounts for the facts presented.\n\nOne possible alternative explanation is that the increase in accidents could be due to an increase in the number of bicyclists on the road. The memo mentions that the number of bicyclists wearing helmets has increased significantly over the past ten years, which could indicate that there are more bicyclists on the road overall. With more bicyclists, there is a higher likelihood of accidents, regardless of whether or not they are wearing helmets. This explanation could be supported by data on the number of bicyclists on the road, which could show an increase in the number of bicyclists over the past decade.\n\nAnother possible explanation is that the increase in accidents could be due to a decrease in the quality of road infrastructure. The memo does not mention any improvements in road infrastructure or safety measures for bicyclists over the past ten years. In fact, it is possible that the roads have become more dangerous for bicyclists due to increased traffic, potholes, or other hazards. If the roads have become more dangerous, bicyclists may be more likely to be involved in accidents, regardless of whether or not they are wearing helmets. This explanation could be supported by data on the condition of roads and infrastructure in Welzaton City.\n\nA third possible explanation is that the increase in accidents could be due to a change in driver behavior. The memo does not mention any changes in driver behavior or attitudes towards bicyclists over the past ten years. However, it is possible that drivers have become less vigilant or more aggressive towards bicyclists, leading to an increase in accidents. This explanation could be supported by data on driver behavior and attitudes towards bicyclists.\n\nIn conclusion, while the proposed explanation for the increase in bicycle-related accidents may seem plausible, there are alternative explanations that could rival it and provide alternative accounts for the facts presented. It is important to consider all possible explanations before drawing conclusions and making decisions based on the data. By considering alternative explanations, we can gain a more complete understanding of the issue and develop effective solutions to address it.", "aae_essay": "There could be several reasons why there has been a 200 percent increase in bike accidents, despite an 80 percent increase in helmet use, aside from the notion that cyclists feel more secure and take more risks while wearing helmets.\n\nFirstly, it's important to consider the fact that there may be more cyclists on the road now than there were ten years ago. As cities become more bike-friendly and cycling becomes a more popular mode of transportation, the number of cyclists on the road increases, which naturally leads to a higher likelihood of accidents. Additionally, with the rise of bike-sharing services and cycling apps, more people are using bikes as a mode of transportation, which could also contribute to the increase in accidents.\n\nSecondly, it's possible that drivers have become less vigilant and less aware of cyclists on the road. With the increasing prevalence of distracted driving due to the use of smartphones and other electronic devices, drivers may be less likely to see and respond to cyclists, leading to a higher number of accidents. Additionally, with the rise of ride-hailing services like Uber and Lyft, there may be more inexperienced drivers on the road who are not familiar with cycling laws and safety protocols.\n\nThirdly, road infrastructure may not have kept pace with the growing number of cyclists. Bike lanes, traffic signals, and other safety measures may not be adequate or well-maintained, which could lead to a higher number of accidents. For example, a bike lane that is poorly maintained or ends abruptly can force cyclists to merge into traffic unexpectedly, increasing the risk of an accident.\n\nFourthly, cyclists themselves may be taking more risks due to factors other than the sense of security provided by helmets. For example, the rise of cycling culture and the popularity of cycling as a form of exercise may lead some cyclists to take risks in order to achieve a faster time or to impress others. Additionally, some cyclists may be less experienced or less knowledgeable about cycling safety protocols, leading them to take unnecessary risks.\n\nLastly, it's possible that the study's findings are skewed by factors such as underreporting of accidents or changes in data collection methods. It's also possible that the study did not control for other factors that could contribute to the increase in accidents, such as changes in weather patterns or road conditions.\n\nIn conclusion, while the argument that cyclists feel more secure in their helmets and therefore take more risks is a plausible one, it's unlikely that this is the sole reason for the 200 percent increase in bike accidents. Other factors such as an increase in the number of cyclists, less vigilant drivers, inadequate road infrastructure, risky behavior by cyclists, and methodological issues with the study could also contribute to the rise in accidents. Therefore, it's important to consider all these factors when addressing the issue of bike safety and to implement measures that address these issues comprehensively.", "esl_essay": "The memo published by the Welzaton City Commission suggests that the increase in serious accidents involving bicycles can be attributed to bicyclists taking more risks due to a false sense of security provided by wearing helmets. However, there are alternative explanations that could rival this proposed explanation and provide alternative accounts for the facts presented in the argument.\n\nOne possible alternative explanation is that the increase in accidents could be due to an increase in the number of bicyclists on the road. The memo mentions that the number of bicyclists wearing helmets has increased significantly over the past ten years, which could indicate that there are more bicyclists on the road overall. This increase in the number of bicyclists could lead to a higher likelihood of accidents, regardless of whether or not the bicyclists are wearing helmets. Additionally, as cities become more densely populated and urbanized, there may be more traffic and more potential hazards for bicyclists to contend with, further increasing the risk of accidents.\n\nAnother possible explanation is that the design and safety features of bicycles have not kept pace with the increasing number of bicyclists. While helmets can provide some protection, they are not a foolproof solution to preventing accidents. Other safety features such as better brakes, reflectors, and lights, as well as improved road design and infrastructure, could be more effective in reducing the number of accidents. If bicycles and roads have not been designed with safety in mind, bicyclists may still be at risk of accidents even if they are wearing helmets.\n\nFurthermore, the local survey cited in the memo suggests that 75 percent of frequent bicycle riders feel safer when they wear helmets. However, this does not necessarily mean that they are taking more risks. It is possible that bicyclists who wear helmets are simply more aware of their surroundings and more cautious in general, leading to a lower risk of accidents. This could be due to a variety of factors, such as increased visibility, better situational awareness, or a greater sense of responsibility.\n\nIn conclusion, while the proposed explanation for the rise in bicycle-related accidents suggests that bicyclists are taking more risks due to a false sense of security provided by helmets, there are alternative explanations that could plausibly account for the facts presented in the argument. The increase in the number of bicyclists on the road, inadequate safety features of bicycles and roads, and the possibility that helmet-wearing bicyclists are simply more cautious and aware of their surroundings are all alternative explanations that could rival the proposed explanation. Therefore, it is important to consider all possible explanations before drawing conclusions about the cause of the increase in bicycle-related accidents."}
{"index": 515, "sae_prompt": "According to a recent report, cheating among college and university students is on the rise. However, Groveton College has successfully reduced student cheating by adopting an honor code, which calls for students to agree not to cheat in their academic endeavors and to notify a faculty member if they suspect that others have cheated. Groveton's honor code replaced a system in which teachers closely monitored students; under that system, teachers reported an average of thirty cases of cheating per year. In the first year the honor code was in place, students reported twenty-one cases of cheating; five years later, this figure had dropped to fourteen. Moreover, in a recent survey, a majority of Groveton students said that they would be less likely to cheat with an honor code in place than without. Thus, all colleges and universities should adopt honor codes similar to Groveton's in order to decrease cheating among students.\nWrite a response in which you discuss what questions would need to be answered in order to decide whether the recommendation and the argument on which it is based are reasonable. Be sure to explain how the answers to these questions would help to evaluate the recommendation.", "aae_prompt": "According to what folks been sayin', cheatin' at colleges and universities is gettin' more common. Before all that, teachers had to keep a tight watch on students, and they used to catch like thirty cheaters a year. When they put that honor code in play, students called out twenty-one cheaters the first year, and then after five years, that number fell to just fourteen. Plus, a recent poll showed most Groveton students say they less likely to cheat if there's an honor code. So, the word is all colleges and universities oughta get on board with honor codes like Groveton's to cut down on cheatin'.\n\nNow, write up somethin' talkin' 'bout what kinda questions we gotta answer to figure if this suggestion and the thinkin' behind it make sense. Make sure you break down how the answers to these questions gon' help check if the recommendation is solid.", "esl_prompt": "According to recent report, cheating among college and university students is on the rise. However, Groveton College has successful reduced student cheating by adopting an honor code, which calls for students to agree not cheat in their academic endeavors and to notify a faculty member if they suspect that others have cheated. Groveton's honor code replaced a system where teachers closely monitored students; under that system, teachers reported an average of thirty cases of cheating per year. In the first year the honor code was in place, students reported twenty-one cases of cheating; five years later, this number had dropped to fourteen. Moreover, in a recent survey, a majority of Groveton students said that they would be less likely to cheat with an honor code in place than without. Thus, all colleges and universities should adopt honor codes similar to Groveton's in order to decrease cheating among students.\nWrite a response in which you discuss what questions would need to be answer in order to decide whether the recommendation and the argument on which it is based are reasonable. Be sure to explain how the answers to these question would help to evaluate the recommendation.", "sae_essay": "A recommendation that all colleges and universities should adopt honor codes similar to Groveton's in order to decrease cheating among students is based on a report that cheating among college and university students is on the rise. The report also states that Groveton College successfully reduced student cheating by adopting an honor code, which calls for students to agree not to cheat in their academic endeavors and to notify a faculty member if they suspect that others have cheated. However, before accepting this recommendation as reasonable, several questions need to be answered.\n\nFirst, it is important to know whether Groveton's honor code is the only factor responsible for the reduction in cheating cases. The report mentions that the college replaced a system in which teachers closely monitored students with the honor code. Therefore, it is possible that the reduction in cheating cases could be attributed to the change in monitoring systems rather than the honor code itself. To evaluate the recommendation, it is necessary to know whether there were any other factors that could have contributed to the decrease in cheating.\n\nSecond, it is important to consider the potential drawbacks of implementing an honor code. While the report states that a majority of Groveton students said they would be less likely to cheat with an honor code in place, it is possible that some students may feel pressured to sign the honor code, even if they do not intend to abide by it. Additionally, an honor code may create a culture of fear where students are reluctant to ask for help or collaborate with their peers for fear of being accused of cheating. Before adopting such a system, it is important to consider whether the potential benefits outweigh the potential drawbacks.\n\nThird, it would be useful to know how the honor code is enforced and whether it is effective in all cases. The report states that students are expected to notify a faculty member if they suspect that others have cheated, but it does not specify how these reports are handled or whether they always lead to consequences for the accused. Furthermore, it is possible that some students may be reluctant to report their peers, especially if they fear retaliation or do not believe that anything will come of it.\n\nLastly, it would be important to consider the cultural and contextual factors that may influence the effectiveness of an honor code. Groveton College may have a unique culture that makes an honor code more effective than it would be at other institutions. Additionally, the report does not provide information about the specific types of cheating that were reduced, which could be important in evaluating the effectiveness of the honor code.\n\nIn conclusion, while the recommendation to adopt honor codes similar to Groveton's may have some merit, several questions need to be answered before accepting it as reasonable. It is important to consider the potential drawbacks, the effectiveness of the honor code, and the cultural and contextual factors that may influence its success. By answering these questions, colleges and universities can make a more informed decision about whether implementing an honor code is the best way to reduce cheating among their students.", "aae_essay": "It's a mighty fine idea to consider implementin' honor codes at colleges and universities to reduce cheatin', but we gotta do some investigatin' first. Now, I ain't sayin' it's a bad idea, but we gotta answer some questions to see if it's the best way to go.\n\nFirst off, we gotta wonder, what's the real reason for cheatin' in the first place? Is it 'cause students are lazy and don't wanna put in the work? Or is it 'cause the pressure to succeed is too high, and they feel like they gotta cheat to keep up? If it's the latter, an honor code might not solve the problem, 'cause students'll still feel that pressure. We gotta figure out the root cause, so we can tackle it head-on.\n\nAnother thing we gotta consider is, how effective are honor codes, really? Sure, Groveton College saw a decrease in cheatin' when they implemented their code, but that don't necessarily mean it'll work everywhere. Maybe Groveton's students are different, or maybe they just got scared straight when they heard about the honor code. We need to research how well honor codes work at other colleges and universities to know if it's a solution that'll work across the board.\n\nAnd let's not forget, there's different kinds of cheatin'. Some students might cheat on tests, while others might plagiarize their papers. An honor code might not cover all types of cheatin', so we gotta think about how we can address all forms of dishonesty. Maybe we need to give students more resources to help 'em understand how to properly cite their sources, or how to prepare for tests without cheatin'.\n\nWe also gotta consider the potential downsides of honor codes. Some students might feel like they're bein' watched, and that can create a culture of mistrust. If students feel like they're bein' accused of cheatin' just 'cause they're lookin' at their neighbor's paper, that's gonna create a hostile learnin' environment. We gotta make sure that any honor code we implement don't make students feel like they're bein' judged all the time.\n\nLastly, we gotta think about how we're gonna enforce this thing. Are we gonna have students sign a piece of paper sayin' they won't cheat? Are we gonna have teachers monitorin' students like hawks? We need to figure out how we're gonna make sure students are followin' the honor code, without makin' 'em feel like they're in a police state.\n\nIn conclusion, while implementin' honor codes might be a good idea, we gotta do our due diligence to make sure it's the right solution. We gotta figure out why students are cheatin', how effective honor codes are, how we can address all forms of cheatin', how to create a positive learnin' environment, and how to enforce the code without bein' too strict. If we can answer these questions, then we can decide if implementin' honor codes is the way to go.", "esl_essay": "It is a good thing that Groveton College has been successful in reducing student cheating through the adoption of an honor code. However, the recommendation that all colleges and universities should adopt a similar honor code may not be reasonable without further investigation. Before adopting such a policy, several questions need to be answered.\n\nFirst, what is the definition of cheating? Different institutions may have different definitions, and it is important to know whether Groveton's definition is the same as other colleges and universities. Moreover, what are the consequences of cheating at Groveton College? Are they stricter than those at other institutions? If so, it may be the fear of consequences rather than the honor code that has led to the reduction in cheating.\n\nSecond, how does the honor code work? Is it simply a set of rules that students are required to follow, or are there consequences for not following them? Is there a system in place for reporting and investigating allegations of cheating? How are the allegations handled, and by whom? It is important to know whether the honor code is enforced fairly and consistently.\n\nThird, what is the culture of Groveton College? Is it a culture that values academic integrity and honesty? If so, it may be that the honor code is successful because it aligns with the values of the students and faculty. However, if the culture at other colleges and universities is different, an honor code may not be as effective.\n\nFourth, what are the reasons why students cheat? Is it because they feel pressure to get good grades, or is it because they lack the skills and knowledge to complete the work on their own? If it is the former, an honor code may help to alleviate the pressure by emphasizing the importance of academic integrity. However, if it is the latter, an honor code alone may not be enough to address the root cause of cheating.\n\nFifth, how does the honor code affect students who may be struggling academically? Does it provide them with additional support and resources, or does it simply penalize them for cheating? It is important to ensure that students who are struggling are not unfairly targeted by an honor code.\n\nFinally, how does the honor code impact diversity and inclusion on campus? Does it create a culture of mistrust and suspicion, or does it foster a sense of community and shared values? It is important to ensure that the honor code does not disproportionately impact certain groups of students.\n\nIn conclusion, while Groveton College's honor code may be effective in reducing cheating, it is important to answer these questions before adopting a similar policy at other colleges and universities. Each institution is unique, and what works at one institution may not work at another. By carefully considering these questions, we can determine whether an honor code is the best approach to reducing cheating and promoting academic integrity."}
{"index": 514, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in an article written by Dr. Karp, an anthropologist.\n\"Twenty years ago, Dr. Field, a noted anthropologist, visited the island of Tertia and concluded from his observations that children in Tertia were reared by an entire village rather than by their own biological parents. However, my recent interviews with children living in the group of islands that includes Tertia show that these children spend much more time talking about their biological parents than about other adults in the village. This research of mine proves that Dr. Field's conclusion about Tertian village culture is invalid and thus that the observation-centered approach to studying cultures is invalid as well. The interview-centered method that my team of graduate students is currently using in Tertia will establish a much more accurate understanding of child-rearing traditions there and in other island cultures.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what specific evidence is needed to evaluate the argument and explain how the evidence would weaken or strengthen the argument.", "aae_prompt": "Check it, this what Dr. Karp, who be an anthropologist, had to say in one article:\n\n\"Bout twenty years back, Dr. Field, who errbody know as a big-time anthropologist, hit up Tertia island and came to the conclusion from what he peeped that the kids over there was bein' raised by the whole village, not just they own moms and pops. But yo, my fresh talks with the shorties stayin' in the islands 'round Tertia, including Tertia itself, show these youngins be chattin' way more 'bout they biological folks than 'bout other grown folks in the village. This work I been doin' knock down Dr. Field's say-so 'bout how Tertian village culture get down, and it's throwin' shade on that whole watch-and-learn way of diggin' into cultures too. The way me and my grad students getting down with these interviews in Tertia, that's gon' lay down the real deal 'bout how they do that child-rearing thing there and in other island spots.\"\n\nNow, you gotta come up with a piece where you talk 'bout what kinda proof you need to check out Dr. Karp's argument, and break down how that proof might make his argument look strong or kinda shaky.", "esl_prompt": "The following appeared in an article written by Dr. Karp, an anthropologist.\n\"Twenty year ago, Dr. Field, a noted anthropologist, visited the island of Tertia and concluded from his observation that children in Tertia was reared by an entire village rather than by their own biological parents. However, my recent interview with children living in the group of islands that includes Tertia shows that these children spends much more time talking about their biological parents than about other adults in the village. This research of mine prove that Dr. Field's conclusion about Tertian village culture is not valid and thus that the observation-centered approach to studying cultures is not valid as well. The interview-centered method that my team of graduate students is currently using in Tertia will establish a much more accurate understanding of child-rearing traditions there and in other island cultures.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what specific evidence is needed to evaluate the argument and explain how the evidence would weaken or strengthen the argument.", "sae_essay": "The argument presented by Dr. Karp in the given passage is that Dr. Field's conclusion about Tertian village culture, which was based on observation, is invalid, and that the interview-centered method used by Dr. Karp's team will establish a more accurate understanding of child-rearing traditions in Tertia and other island cultures. To evaluate this argument, we need to consider several factors.\n\nFirstly, it is important to note that Dr. Karp's research only interviewed children living in the group of islands that includes Tertia, and not children from Tertia specifically. This raises questions about the validity of generalizing the findings to Tertia alone. Additionally, the passage does not provide information about the sample size of children interviewed or their age range, which could affect the reliability of the data. A larger and more diverse sample size would be needed to accurately represent the child-rearing traditions of Tertia.\n\nFurthermore, it is not clear how Dr. Karp's interviews with children were conducted, what questions were asked, and how the data was analyzed. Were the interviews structured or unstructured? Were they conducted in the children's native language or in a language they were not familiar with? How were the responses coded and analyzed? These methodological details are crucial in determining the validity and reliability of the findings.\n\nAnother important factor to consider is that Dr. Field's observation-centered approach may have been influenced by various factors that Dr. Karp's interview-centered approach may not have accounted for. For instance, Dr. Field may have observed children interacting with multiple caregivers in the village, which could have led him to conclude that the children were being reared by the entire village. Dr. Karp's interviews, on the other hand, may have focused more on the children's relationships with their biological parents, which could have led to a different conclusion.\n\nIn order to strengthen Dr. Karp's argument, it would be necessary to provide more detailed information about the methodology used in the interviews, including the sample size, age range, and method of data analysis. Additionally, Dr. Karp could have conducted observations in addition to interviews to triangulate the data and provide a more comprehensive understanding of child-rearing traditions in Tertia.\n\nIn conclusion, while Dr. Karp's argument challenges Dr. Field's conclusion about Tertian village culture, there are several limitations to the evidence presented. To fully evaluate the argument, more information is needed about the methodology used in the interviews, as well as a more diverse and representative sample size. Additionally, Dr. Karp's argument would be strengthened by incorporating observation data to complement the interview data. Ultimately, a more comprehensive study that considers multiple perspectives and methods is necessary to establish a accurate understanding of child-rearing traditions in Tertia and other island cultures.", "aae_essay": "When it comes to Dr. Karp's argument that the children on Tertia island are primarily raised by their biological parents and not the entire village, as Dr. Field previously suggested, there are a few key pieces of evidence that would be necessary to support or refute this claim.\n\nFirst and foremost, it would be important to conduct a thorough examination of the daily lives of the children on Tertia island. This could involve observing the interactions between children and their caregivers, as well as interviewing both the children and their parents to gain a better understanding of their relationships and the roles that each play in the children's upbringing.\n\nAdditionally, it would be helpful to compare the experiences of children on Tertia island to those of children on other islands in the region, as Dr. Karp suggests doing in his statement. This could provide valuable insight into whether the child-rearing practices on Tertia island are unique or if they are similar to those of other cultures in the area.\n\nFurthermore, it would be useful to examine the cultural and historical context of Tertia island to better understand the evolution of their child-rearing practices. For example, it may be helpful to investigate whether the island has a history of strong family ties or if there have been any significant cultural or societal changes that may have influenced the way children are raised.\n\nIn terms of the evidence that Dr. Karp provides, his interviews with children and grad students on Tertia island and other nearby islands are a good starting point. If this evidence is robust and consistently supports Dr. Karp's claims, then his argument may be considered strong. However, if the evidence is limited or inconsistent, then his argument may be considered shaky.", "esl_essay": "Dr. Karp's argument that the observation-centered approach to studying cultures is not valid, based on his recent interview with children living in the group of islands that includes Tertia, requires further evidence to be fully evaluated. {"index": 512, "sae_prompt": "The following is a memorandum from the business manager of a television station.\n\"Over the past year, our late-night news program has devoted increased time to national news and less time to weather and local news. This recommendation is based on the assumption that the station's previous decision to devote more time to national news and less time to weather and local news led to a decrease in viewer satisfaction and a loss of advertising revenue. However, this assumption is not explicitly supported by any data or evidence.\n\nFurthermore, the memorandum assumes that viewers who complained about the lack of weather and local news are representative of the general viewing audience. However, it is possible that these viewers are a vocal minority, and that the majority of viewers are actually satisfied with the current format of the news program. Additionally, the memorandum assumes that local businesses that canceled their advertising contracts did so solely because of the station's reduced coverage of weather and local news, which may not be the case.\n\nMoreover, the memorandum assumes that expanding coverage of weather and local news will automatically attract more viewers and appease advertisers. However, this assumption may not hold up under closer scrutiny.\n\nFirstly, the assumption that viewers are primarily interested in local news and weather is not necessarily true. In this case, increasing local news and weather coverage may not be enough to convince them to return to advertising on the station.\n\nFurthermore, the assumption that viewers are only interested in local news and weather and not national news is also not necessarily true. {"index": 511, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in a memorandum from the manager of WWAC radio station.\n\"To reverse a decline in listener numbers, our owners have decided that WWAC must change from its current rock-music format. The decline has occurred despite population growth in our listening area, but that growth has resulted mainly from people moving here after their retirement. We must make listeners of these new residents. We could switch to a music format tailored to their tastes, but a continuing decline in local sales of recorded music suggests limited interest in music. Instead we should change to a news and talk format, a form of radio that is increasingly popular in our area.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what specific evidence is needed to evaluate the argument and explain how the evidence would weaken or strengthen the argument.", "aae_prompt": "Check it, dis memo came from the big boss at WWAC radio station.\n\"To get our listener numbers back up, our head honchos done decided WWAC gotta flip the script from the rock music we been playin'. The decline has happened despite population growth in our listening area, but that growth has resulted mainly from people moving here after their retirement. We must make listeners of these new resident. We could switch to a music format tailored to their taste, but a continuing decline in local sales of recorded music suggest limited interest in music. The argument is based on the observation that the decline in listener numbers has occurred despite population growth in the listening area, and that this growth has been driven by retirees moving to the area. The argument assumes that these new residents are not interested in rock music, and that a news and talk format would be more appealing to them.\n\nIn order to evaluate this argument, we would need to consider several pieces of evidence. Firstly, we would need data on the demographics of the listening area, including the age range and interests of the new residents. If the data shows that the majority of new residents are indeed retirees who are not interested in rock music, then this would support the argument for changing the format. However, if the data shows that the new residents are a diverse group with a range of interests, including rock music, then this would weaken the argument.\n\nSecondly, we would need data on the popularity of news and talk radio in the listening area. If the data shows that news and talk radio is increasingly popular in the area, as the argument suggests, then this would support the argument for changing the format. However, if the data shows that news and talk radio is not particularly popular, or that there are already other stations in the area that cater to this format, then this would weaken the argument.\n\nThirdly, we would need data on the financial performance of WWAC radio station. If the station is struggling financially, then the argument for changing the format to attract new listeners and increase revenue would be stronger. However, if the station is financially stable, then the argument for change would be weaker.\n\nFinally, we would need to consider the potential risks and drawbacks of changing the format. For example, if WWAC has a strong brand identity as a rock music station, then changing the format could alienate existing listeners and damage the station's reputation. Additionally, changing the format could also result in a loss of talent and expertise among the station's current staff and DJs.\n\nIn conclusion, the argument to change WWAC radio station's format from rock music to news and talk is based on several assumptions that require further evidence to be evaluated effectively. While the argument has some merit, it is important to consider all available data and potential risks before making a decision. Ultimately, a thorough analysis of the evidence would be necessary to determine whether changing the format would be the best course of action for WWAC.", "aae_essay": "Here's a possible essay in response to the prompt:\n\nThe memo from the big boss at WWAC radio station suggests that the station should change its format from rock music to news and talk in order to attract a new audience of retirees who are not interested in music. However, before implementing this plan, it's important to consider several factors to determine whether it's the best course of action.\n\nFirstly, it's important to examine the demographics of the local population to determine the age range of the listeners and their preferences. If the majority of the population in the area are indeed retirees, then it may be beneficial to switch to a format that caters to their interests. However, if the demographics show that there are still a significant number of younger listeners who enjoy rock music, then it may not be wise to completely abandon the current format.\n\nSecondly, it's important to look at the sales data of local music stores to determine whether the decline in sales is a result of a shift in listener preferences or due to other factors such as the rise of streaming services. If the decline in sales is due to a shift in preferences, then switching to a news and talk format may be a good idea. However, if the decline is due to other factors, then it may be premature to abandon the current format.\n\nThirdly, it's important to conduct market research to determine what type of content listeners in the area are interested in. This can be done through surveys, focus groups, and social media engagement. If the research shows that listeners are interested in news and talk, then switching to that format may be a good idea. However, if the research shows that listeners still enjoy rock music, then it may be better to maintain the current format or find a way to incorporate both rock music and news and talk.\n\nLastly, it's important to consider the competition in the local radio market. If other radio stations in the area are already offering news and talk formats, then switching to that format may not be enough to differentiate WWAC from its competitors. In this case, it may be better to find a niche that sets WWAC apart from other stations.\n\nIn conclusion, before implementing the plan to switch to a news and talk format, it's important to consider several factors to determine whether it's the best course of action. These factors include demographics, sales data, market research, and competition. By examining these factors, WWAC can make an informed decision that will help it attract a larger audience and increase its listener numbers.\n\nThe proof that would support this argument could come in the form of data and statistics. For example, data on the demographics of the local population, sales data from local music stores, and survey results from market research could all be used to support the argument. This data could be obtained from government census reports, market research firms, and surveys conducted by WWAC.\n\nThe data could make the argument stronger by providing concrete evidence to support the claims made in the essay. For example, if the data shows that the majority of the local population is indeed made up of retirees, then it would support the idea that switching to a news and talk format would be beneficial. Similarly, if the data shows that sales of rock music are declining, then it would support the idea that the current format is not as popular as it once was.\n\nHowever, if the data shows that there are still a significant number of younger listeners who enjoy rock music, then it could weaken the argument for switching to a news and talk format. Additionally, if the data shows that listeners are interested in a format that incorporates both rock music and news and talk, then it could suggest that WWAC should consider a hybrid format rather than completely abandoning its current format.\n\nOverall, the data and statistics used to support the argument should be reliable, accurate, and relevant to the topic at hand. By using concrete evidence, WWAC can make an informed decision that will help it attract a larger audience and increase its listener numbers.", "esl_essay": "The argument put forth by the manager of WWAC radio station is that the station should change its format from rock music to news and talk in order to reverse a decline in listener numbers. The manager bases this argument on two main points: 1) population growth in the listening area has resulted mainly from people moving there after retirement, and 2) a decline in local sales of recorded music suggests limited interest in music.\n\nIn order to evaluate this argument, we would need to consider several pieces of evidence. Firstly, we would need data on the demographics of the listening area to determine whether the population growth is indeed primarily made up of retirees. If the data shows that the majority of new residents are indeed retirees, then this would support the manager's first point. However, if the data shows that the population growth is diverse and includes a significant number of younger people, then this would weaken the argument for changing the format to news and talk.\n\nSecondly, we would need data on the listening preferences of the local population, particularly among retirees. If research shows that retirees in the area tend to prefer news and talk radio, then this would support the manager's argument. However, if research shows that retirees in the area prefer rock music or other formats, then this would weaken the argument for changing the format.\n\nThirdly, we would need data on the performance of other news and talk radio stations in the area. If other stations with a similar format are experiencing significant listener growth, then this would support the manager's argument. However, if other news and talk stations are also experiencing declining listener numbers, then this would suggest that the format change may not be the solution to WWAC's problem.\n\nFinally, we would need to consider the potential impact of the format change on WWAC's current listener base. If a significant portion of the station's current listeners are rock music fans, then switching to a news and talk format could alienate them and result in a further decline in listener numbers.\n\nIn conclusion, the manager's argument for changing WWAC's format to news and talk is based on two main points. To evaluate this argument, we would need to consider several pieces of evidence, including demographic data, listening preferences, performance of other stations, and potential impact on current listeners. Depending on the outcome of this analysis, the argument could be strengthened or weakened. Ultimately, a thorough evaluation of the evidence would be necessary to determine the best course of action for WWAC radio station."}
{"index": 510, "sae_prompt": "The following memorandum is from the business manager of Happy Pancake House restaurants.\n\"Recently, butter has been replaced by margarine in Happy Pancake House restaurants throughout the southwestern United States. However, there are alternative explanations that could rival the proposed explanation and plausibly account for the facts presented in the argument.\n\nOne possible alternative explanation is that customers who ask for butter may not be aware that they are being given margarine instead. For example, a customer may ask for butter without specifying what type of butter they want, and the server may assume that they are asking for margarine. In this case, the customer may not realize that they have been given margarine instead of butter.\n\nAnother possible explanation is that customers who ask for butter may be willing to accept margarine as a substitute, even if they prefer butter. This could be due to a variety of factors, such as a desire to avoid conflict or a belief that margarine is a healthier option. For instance, a customer may ask for butter but then accept margarine without complaining because they do not want to make a fuss or because they believe that margarine is a healthier choice.\n\nFurthermore, it is also possible that customers who do not complain when given margarine instead of butter may still be dissatisfied with the substitution. However, this does not necessarily mean that they are happy with the change. If customers are not familiar with these differences, they might not be able to tell the difference between the two, or they might assume that margarine is simply a cheaper or lower-quality version of butter.\n\nThirdly, it's possible that customers who request butter are not actually looking for the traditional butter that they think they are getting. {"index": 509, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared as part of an article in a business magazine.\n\"A recent study rating 300 male and female Mentian advertising executives according to the average number of hours they sleep per night showed an association between the amount of sleep the executives need and the success of their firms. These results suggest that if a business wants to prosper, it should hire only people who need less than 6 hours of sleep per night.\"\nWrite a response in which you examine the stated and/or unstated assumptions of the argument. {"index": 508, "sae_prompt": "In an attempt to improve highway safety, Prunty County last year lowered its speed limit from 55 to 45 miles per hour on all county highways. But this effort has failed: the number of accidents has not decreased, and, based on reports by the highway patrol, many drivers are exceeding the speed limit. Prunty County should instead undertake the same kind of road improvement project that Butler County completed five years ago: increasing lane widths, resurfacing rough highways, and improving visibility at dangerous intersections. Today, major Butler County roads still have a 55 mph speed limit, yet there were 25 percent fewer reported accidents in Butler County this past year than there were five years ago.\nWrite a response in which you discuss what specific evidence is needed to evaluate the argument and explain how the evidence would weaken or strengthen the argument.", "aae_prompt": "Last year, Prunty County done dropped the speed limit from 55 to 45 on all them county highways, tryna make 'em safer. Now, Prunty County needa think 'bout doing like Butler County did, like five years back: they made them lanes wider, fixed up the rough roads, and made it easier to see at them bad intersections. Over in Butler County, they still rolling at 55 mph on the big roads, but check it \u2013 they got 25 percent less accidents reported last year than they did five years ago.\n\nSo, you gotta write 'bout what kinda proof we need to check out the argument, and break down how that proof might make the argument weaker or stronger.", "esl_prompt": "In attempt for improve highway safety, Prunty County last year lowered speed limit from 55 to 45 miles per hour on all county highways. But this effort has fail: the number of accidents not decreased, and, based on reports by the highway patrol, many drivers are exceeding the speed limit. Prunty County should instead to undertake the same kind of road improvement project that Butler County completed five years ago: increasing lane widths, resurfacing rough highways, and improving visibility at dangerous intersections. Today, major Butler County roads still have a 55 mph speed limit, yet there was 25 percent fewer reported accidents in Butler County this past year than there was five years ago.\nWrite a response in which you discuss what specific evidences is needed to evaluate the argument and explain how the evidence would weaken or strengthen the argument.", "sae_essay": "The argument that Prunty County should undertake the same kind of road improvement project that Butler County completed five years ago is based on the premise that the lower speed limit implemented in Prunty County has failed to improve highway safety, and that Butler County's road improvements have led to a reduction in accidents. However, to properly evaluate this argument, additional evidence is needed.\nFirstly, it is necessary to examine the reasons behind the failure of the lower speed limit in Prunty County. For instance, was the lower speed limit properly enforced, or did lack of enforcement contribute to its ineffectiveness? Additionally, were there other factors that may have contributed to the lack of improvement in highway safety, such as an increase in the number of vehicles on the road or a lack of driver education campaigns?\nSecondly, it is important to consider the specific road improvements made in Butler County and whether they are applicable to Prunty County's road network. For example, if Butler County's road improvements primarily focused on increasing lane widths, resurfacing rough highways, and improving visibility at dangerous intersections, but Prunty County's roads have different safety concerns, such as sharp curves or inadequate lighting, then the same improvements may not be effective in Prunty County.\nFurthermore, it would be useful to compare the driver behavior and road conditions in both counties. For instance, if drivers in Prunty County are more reckless or aggressive than those in Butler County, then improved road conditions alone may not be enough to improve safety. Similarly, if the road conditions in Prunty County are significantly worse than those in Butler County, then even the best road improvements may not be able to offset the safety risks posed by poor road conditions.\nLastly, it would be helpful to examine the long-term impact of the road improvements in Butler County. While there were 25 percent fewer reported accidents in Butler County this past year compared to five years ago, it is possible that this reduction is a result of factors other than the road improvements, such as changes in driver behavior or economic conditions.\nIn conclusion, while the argument that Prunty County should undertake the same kind of road improvement project as Butler County has some merit, it is important to consider a range of factors before making a decision. Additional evidence is needed to evaluate the effectiveness of the lower speed limit in Prunty County, the applicability of Butler County's road improvements to Prunty County's roads, and the long-term impact of the road improvements in Butler County. Only with this information can a well-informed decision be made about how best to improve highway safety in Prunty County.", "aae_essay": "Prunty County's decision to reduce the speed limit on its county highways from 55 to 45 was intended to improve road safety. However, the effectiveness of this policy change is disputed, with some arguing that it has not made a significant difference in reducing accidents. In contrast, Butler County's approach of widening lanes, improving road conditions, and enhancing visibility at intersections has led to a 25% reduction in accidents over the past five years. This raises the question of whether Prunty County should adopt a similar approach to road safety.\n\nWhen evaluating the effectiveness of Prunty County's speed limit reduction, it is important to consider various types of evidence. Firstly, data on the number of accidents that have occurred since the policy change can provide insight into whether the reduction in speed limit has led to a decrease in accidents. If the data shows that the number of accidents has not significantly decreased, it could suggest that the policy change has not been effective.\n\nHowever, it is also important to consider other factors that may influence road safety, such as driver behavior and road conditions. For example, if drivers are not adhering to the new speed limit, this could negate any potential safety benefits. In this case, data on compliance with the speed limit would be useful in assessing the effectiveness of the policy. Additionally, if road conditions are poor or visibility is limited at intersections, this could also contribute to accidents, regardless of the speed limit.\n\nIn comparison, Butler County's approach to road safety has been successful, with a significant reduction in accidents reported. This suggests that their strategy, which focuses on improving road infrastructure and visibility, may be a more effective way to improve road safety. However, it is important to note that Butler County's roads and traffic patterns may differ from those in Prunty County, so a direct comparison may not be appropriate.\n\nIn conclusion, to assess the effectiveness of Prunty County's speed limit reduction, it is necessary to consider a range of factors and data sources. While a simple comparison of accident rates may suggest that the policy has not been effective, a more nuanced analysis that takes into account driver behavior, road conditions, and other factors may provide a more accurate picture. Ultimately, Prunty County may benefit from adopting a similar approach to road safety as Butler County, which has led to a significant reduction in accidents.", "esl_essay": "It is not enough to claim that Prunty County should adopt Butler County's road improvement project simply because Butler County's roads have a 55 mph speed limit and fewer accidents. To properly evaluate this argument, we need more specific evidence.\n\nFirst, we need to consider the road conditions in both counties before and after the improvements. If Butler County's roads were in worse condition than Prunty County's before the improvements, then it would make sense that they saw a greater reduction in accidents after making improvements. On the other hand, if Prunty County's roads were already in good condition, then it may not be necessary to implement the same improvements.\n\nSecond, we need to consider the driver behavior in both counties. If drivers in Butler County were more reckless than drivers in Prunty County before the improvements, then it would make sense that they saw a greater reduction in accidents after implementing safety measures. However, if drivers in Prunty County are generally more cautious, then the same improvements may not have the same impact.\n\nThird, we need to consider other factors that may affect the number of accidents, such as traffic volume, road design, and weather conditions. If there are significant differences in these factors between the two counties, then it may not be fair to compare their accident rates.\n\nFourth, we need to consider the specific improvements made in Butler County. Simply increasing lane widths, resurfacing rough highways, and improving visibility at dangerous intersections may not be enough to explain the reduction in accidents. Perhaps Butler County also implemented other safety measures, such as installing traffic lights or improving road signs, that contributed to the decrease in accidents.\n\nLastly, we need to consider the time frame in which the improvements were made. If Butler County's improvements were made several years ago, then it may be too early to see the full impact on accident rates. Additionally, it's possible that other factors, such as changes in driver behavior or increased enforcement of traffic laws, may have contributed to the reduction in accidents over time.\n\nIn conclusion, while it may seem intuitive that Prunty County should adopt Butler County's road improvement project, we need more specific evidence to properly evaluate the argument. By considering the road conditions, driver behavior, other factors that affect accidents, the specific improvements made, and the time frame in which they were made, we can better determine whether Butler County's approach would be effective in Prunty County."}
{"index": 507, "sae_prompt": "Fifteen years ago, Omega University implemented a new procedure that encouraged students to evaluate the teaching effectiveness of all their professors. Potential employers, looking at this dramatic rise in grades, believe that grades at Omega are inflated and do not accurately reflect student achievement; as a result, Omega graduates have not been as successful at getting jobs as have graduates from nearby Alpha University. To enable its graduates to secure better jobs, Omega University should terminate student evaluation of professors.\nWrite a response in which you discuss what specific evidence is needed to evaluate the argument and explain how the evidence would weaken or strengthen the argument.", "aae_prompt": "'Bout fifteen years back, Omega University started lettin' students check how they profs be teachin'. However, to properly evaluate this argument, we need to consider several pieces of evidence.\nFirstly, we need data on the actual performance of Omega graduates in the job market. If the data shows that Omega graduates are indeed struggling to secure jobs despite their high grades, then this would support the argument that employers perceive Omega grades as inflated and do not accurately reflect student achievement. On the other hand, if Omega graduates are performing well in the job market, then this would suggest that employers do not have a biased view of Omega grades and that the rise in grades is a reflection of genuine improvements in student performance.\nSecondly, we need to consider the reasons behind the rise in grades at Omega. If the rise in grades is indeed due to inflated grading, then this would support the argument that student evaluations should be terminated. However, if the rise in grades is due to other factors, such as improved teaching methods or increased student motivation, then this would weaken the argument for terminating student evaluations.\nAdditionally, we need to consider the potential consequences of terminating student evaluations. While doing so might improve the perception of Omega grades among employers, it could also have negative consequences for students. Student evaluations provide valuable feedback to professors, which can help them improve their teaching methods and better support their students. Terminating student evaluations could result in professors receiving less feedback and, therefore, being less effective in the classroom.\nFurthermore, we need to consider alternative solutions to address the issue of perceived grade inflation. One possible solution could be to implement a more rigorous grading system that is less susceptible to bias. This could involve implementing a standardized grading rubric or increasing the use of objective assessments, such as exams and quizzes.\nIn conclusion, while the argument that Omega University should terminate student evaluation of professors to improve its graduates' job prospects has some merit, it is based on a number of assumptions that require further investigation. To properly evaluate this argument, we need to consider a range of evidence, including data on Omega graduates' job prospects, the reasons behind the rise in grades at Omega, and the potential consequences of terminating student evaluations. {"index": 506, "sae_prompt": "The council of Maple County, concerned about the county's becoming overdeveloped, is debating a proposed measure that would prevent the development of existing farmland in the county. In contrast, a weak economy with high unemployment and low wages may reduce demand for housing, making it less likely that housing prices will increase.\n\nThirdly, the council should consider the potential impact of the proposed measure on the cost of building new homes. {"index": 504, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in the Health section of the Greenhorne Gazette.\n\"Motilac is a substance that occurs naturally in the human digestive tract. Many consumers of dietary supplements containing motilac report significant easing of digestive discomfort after just a few weeks of use. Among Greenhorne residents, the consumption of motilac supplements has increased 80% over the last seven years. Last year, Greenhorne's five hospitals reported fewer cases of serious gastrointestinal disorders than any year on record. Meanwhile, sales of motilac supplements are declining in the neighboring town of Etolin. Notably, hospitals in Etolin report a steady increase in the last two years in patients experiencing a wide range of distressing gastrointestinal symptoms. The clear explanation of these trends is that motilac is effective in preventing many serious gastrointestinal disorders.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss one or more alternative explanations that could rival the proposed explanation and explain how your explanation(s) can plausibly account for the facts presented in the argument.", "aae_prompt": "Check it, dis piece popped up in da Health section of da Greenhorne Gazette.\n\"Motilac be this thing that's all natural-like in folks' guts. Many consumers of dietary supplements containing motilac report significant easing of digestive discomfort after just a few weeks of use. Among Greenhorne residents, the consumption of motilac supplements has increased 80% over the last seven years. Last year, Greenhorne's five hospitals reported fewer cases of serious gastrointestinal disorders than any year on record. Meanwhile, sales of motilac supplements are declining in the neighboring town of Etolin. Notably, hospitals in Etolin report a steady increase in the last two years in patients experiencing a wide range of distressing gastrointestinal symptoms. The clear explanation of these trends is that motilac is effective in preventing many serious gastrointestinal disorders.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss one or more alternative explanations that could rival the proposed explanation and explain how your explanation(s) can plausibly account for the facts presented in the argument.\n\nESL English with Errors:\n\nThe following appeared in the Health section of the Greenhorne Gazette.\n\"Motilac is a substance what occurs naturally in the human digestive tract. Many consumers of dietary supplements containing motilac report significant easing of digestive discomfort after just a few weeks of use. Among Greenhorne residents, the consumption of motilac supplements has increased 80% over the last seven years. Last year, Greenhorne's five hospitals reported fewer cases of serious gastrointestinal disorders than any year on record. Meanwhile, sales of motilac supplements are declining in the neighboring town of Etolin. Notably, hospitals in Etolin report a steady increase in the last two years in patients experiencing a wide range of distressing gastrointestinal symptoms. The clear explanation of these trends is that motilac is effective in preventing many serious gastrointestinal disorders.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss one or more alternative explanations that could rival the proposed explanation and explain how your explanation(s) can plausible account for the facts presented in the argument.", "sae_essay": "It is tempting to attribute the decline in serious gastrointestinal disorders in Greenhorne to the increased consumption of motilac supplements, but there are alternative explanations that could rival this proposed explanation. One possible explanation is that Greenhorne residents have made other lifestyle changes that have contributed to their improved digestive health. For example, they may have increased their consumption of fiber, begun exercising regularly, or reduced their stress levels. These changes could have contributed to the decrease in gastrointestinal disorders, rather than the use of motilac supplements.\n\nAnother possible explanation is that the hospitals in Greenhorne have improved their treatment methods for gastrointestinal disorders, leading to a decrease in reported cases. This could be due to advances in medical technology, changes in medical protocols, or increased funding for gastrointestinal research. It is also possible that patients in Greenhorne are more likely to seek medical attention for gastrointestinal symptoms than patients in Etolin, leading to a higher reported incidence of gastrointestinal disorders in Greenhorne.\n\nFurthermore, it is possible that the decline in motilac supplement sales in Etolin is not due to a lack of effectiveness, but rather due to a lack of awareness of the benefits of motilac. If consumers in Etolin are not aware of the potential benefits of motilac, they may be less likely to purchase supplements containing the substance. This could lead to a steady increase in gastrointestinal disorders, as patients are not receiving the potential benefits of motilac.\n\nIn conclusion, while it may seem logical to attribute the decline in gastrointestinal disorders in Greenhorne to the increased consumption of motilac supplements, there are alternative explanations that could plausibly account for the facts presented in the argument. In contrast, residents of Etolin may have less access to healthcare, leading to a higher incidence of untreated gut issues.\n\nAnother factor that could be at play is differences in diet and lifestyle between the two regions. {"index": 503, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared as a memorandum from the Human Resources director at Dexter Gorman Instruments, a company that manufactures saxophones.\n\"On this year's survey about work habits, our employees tended to strongly agree with the idea that if they took less time to complete their assigned work, the quality of their work would suffer. However, we recently conducted an internal study that proves this idea wrong. Managers across several divisions identified an overtime group: the employees who worked an average of 48 or more hours per week over the past year instead of the expected 40 hours per week. We then looked at the number of documented work errors produced by all of our employees during the past year and found that the overtime group was responsible for significantly more work errors overall than their fellow employees. On the basis of these findings, our recommendation to the company president is to require employees at Dexter Gorman Instruments to complete their work during the regular 40-hour work week and allow overtime only for urgent circumstances.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what questions would need to be answered in order to decide whether the recommendation and the argument on which it is based are reasonable. Be sure to explain how the answers to these questions would help to evaluate the recommendation.", "aae_prompt": "The memo y'all seein' come from the HR director at Dexter Gorman Instruments, where they be makin' saxophones.\n\n\"So check it, on the survey 'bout work habits we did this year, our folks mostly was like, 'Yeah, if we rush through our work, it ain't gon' be as good.' But yo, we just did this study in-house that's callin' that out. The bosses in different parts done spotted a group that been puttin' in overtime: them employees who been workin' like 48 hours or more each week for the last year, instead of the regular 40. Then we peeped the number of mess-ups in work all our people made in the past year, and guess what? Them overtime cats had way more slip-ups than the rest.\n\nBased on what we found, we tellin' the big boss at Dexter Gorman Instruments to have everybody stick to they 40 hours and only do overtime when stuff's really poppin' off.\"\n\nNow, write up somethin' 'bout what kinda questions we gotta get at to figure if this recommendation and the argument it's standin' on make sense.
